title: Economists upbeat but mindful of downside
text:
Fri, Jul 17, 2015, 7:15 PM AEST - Australia Markets closed Economists upbeat but mindful of downside AAP – 41 minutes ago 
Economists this week saw plenty of potential for things to turn out badly, but generally looked on the bright side amid good news on Greece and a halt to the slide in China's share market. 
UBS economists George Tharenou and Scott Haslem saw warning signs in Australian construction figures released on Wednesday. 
Non-residential construction had slumped to near a decade low after a peak-to-trough fall deeper than in the early 1990s recession, they said. 
"After yesterday's rebound in NAB's survey of business conditions implied an economic upturn, in stark contrast today's data thumped home the reality that 'hard data' on non-residential construction commencements support the (view that the) capex cliff is 'recessionary'." 
Then came news on Wednesday of a fall in the monthly Westpac-Melbourne Institute measure of consumer confidence, confirming Tuesday's news that the ANZ-Roy Morgan measure had slumped for the second consecutive week. 
This meant risks for consumption spending, Tharenou and Scott Haslem said. 
But JP Morgan's Ben Jarman warned against over-interpreting the results, which were likely affected by global concerns related to Greece's woes and China's share market. 
"Households are downgrading their assessment of the economy, but do not see that as being particularly relevant for them, with the divergence between the outlook for personal finances vs that for the economy widening further to new cycle highs," he said. 
Even so, a persistent dip in confidence would make an upturn in corporate hiring and investment difficult if households did not come along for the ride, he said. 
CommSec's Craig James downplayed the fall in consumer confidence. 
"The Aussie dollar is stabilising; the Aussie sharemarket is lifting; the Chinese sharemarket appears to be stabilising; and both the Iran and Greek issues look to be heading for resolution," he said. 
"In short, the latest consumer confidence reading may actually prove to be ancient history." 
And, he said, the good news was that both business confidence and business conditions (an average of employment reading conditions and profitability measures) are now both stronger than normal. 
That was a reference to the NAB business confidence survey on Tuesday, which UBS economist George Tharenou said could signal a "turning point" in the economy. 
AMP's Shane Oliver acknowledged that the agreement Greece had made with its creditors faced challenges. 
"Given that the Greek economy will likely get worse before it gets better and debt relief is still a way off (after program reviews) another rebellion by Greece - reopening the prospect of a Grexit (Greek exit from the euro) - remains a risk," he said. 
"But in the short term Greece is likely to fade as an issue." 
As for the Chinese share market's slide, Dr Oliver looked on the bright side, saying the "necessary correction" had limited implications for Australia.
